Within the next few weeks the
record of every student and alumnus of Johns Hopkins University
will be examined to determine the
part which he would be fitted to
play in the event of war with
Germany.
It is planned that, in case of
war, every resource which the
University is able to command
shall be instantly laid at the disposal of the Government, and
that, in the meantime, the Government shall be furnished with a
complete list of the various ways
in which the alumni and students
could be of assistance in defense
and offense.
For this purpose a questionary
will be sent out to the 4,000
alumni and another questionary
will be distributed among the
present postgraduates and undergraduates. Each man will be expected to give a complete record
of his past scientific activities, of
the general line of work in which
he is most interested, and of the
part he would be willing to play
if the warcloud breaks.
This investigation is to be conducted by Dr. Lorraine Sherman
Hulburt, collegiate professor of
mathematics, for the Intercollegiate Intelligence Bureau. When
interviewed by a representative
Of THE NEWS-LETTER, Dr. Hulburt
stated that definite plans for the
carrying on of the work had not
as yet been formulated, but that
the investigation Would be a
thorough one, and would be begun as quickly as possible.
The Hopkins Medical School
has already formed a hospital
unit which could report for service at a day's notice. If war is
declared, Dr. Welch, the head of
the school, as president of the National Academy of Science will
be' one of the mainstays of the
nation.
"Johns Hopkins is at the absolute disposal of the United States
Government," is the statement of
President Goodnow. "Our laboratories and equipment, our hospitals and every member of the
faculty are for our country's service—now, in preparation for war,
no less than when war is declared."

David Jayne Hill, LL. D., the
James Schouler lecturer for 1917,
began a series of lectures on
"International Readjustments" in
the Civil Engineering lecture
room on Tuesday, April, 6. Mr.
Hill was a schoolmate and close
personal friend of the Kaiser, and
is one of the foremost authorities
on international law.
Dr. Hill was introduced by
President Goodnow to an audience that taxed the capacity of
the Civil Engineering hall, with
all the seats filled and people
standing in the rear.
Dr. Hill began his series with
a discussion on "The Shadow of
the Past." He traced the development of the historical European
States from the fall of the Roman
Empire, through to their present
relations in war.
Dr. Hill said, in part, that European history was a conflict between humanism and tribalism.
Religion assumed a unity which it
did not possess and, because it
was not an actual unity, could not
save Europe. He traced the development of powerful national
monarchies through the conflict
between the temporal and spiritual powers, through the fall of
feudalism, to the stage where nations were military forces ruled
by an irresponsible sovereignty.
Dr. Hill maintained that a
State is a moral entity and that
sovereignty includes the obligation of moral justice to other nations. The unlimited right of any
nation to make war for any cause
at all, according to his view, is an
inheritance from absolutism and
should be regulated by international law.
"Neutrality," Dr. Hill said, "is
a long step forward from the Machiavellian doctrine of joining at
the proper moment with the probable winner to enjoy the fruits of
victory." "Nevertheless," he went
on, "neutrality may be highly unmoral."
Dr. Hill went on to show the

"Nations have become the greatest business trusts in the world,"
he said, "and they view other nations as business rivals." After
showing that the present relations
between nations is unsocial and
unethical, Dr. Hill asserted that

The Student Council has presented to the Absence Committee
a petition which states that, in
the opinion of the council, the
new rules in regard to absences
are over-harsh, and asks that they
be in some way modified. The
committee has already announced
that, in future, excuses for absence may be handed in writing,
inStead of being delivered formally, but has made no official
statement as to what other steps
it may be contemplating.
The committee believes that in
eliminating the feature of the
rules which required personal appearance at the committee meetlug before any absence was excused it has eliminated much in
them that was objectionable to
the undergraduates. Under the
new provision all that is necessary is for the student to write
the date and reason of his absence, to address the note to the
Absence Committee, and to pass
it into the box outside the registrar's office.
The chief feature in the new
rules to which the Student Council objected, however, was the
fact that apparently every unexcused absence from class, even
though the number be but one or
two, was to count against the
student's grade in that subject.
In this connection, the committee drew the attention of the
council to the exact reading of
the rule to which they object.
That rule is worded as follows:
"Unexcused absences Will count
against the student's grade in the
subject concerned." No mention
is made of how much those absences should count — the rule
leaves to the discretion of the
committee the fixing of the penalty, and the conditions under
which such a penalty is to be imposed.
Although no official statement
has been made by the committee,
there are persistent rumors afloat
to the effect that, if the number of
unexcused absences under the
new rules is small, it is very probable that only unexcused absences
after the second will .count
against the term grade.
It is also rumored that, al- .
though the first two unexcused
absences might not be counted,
three such absences would take
off five from the student's term
grade.

Tryouts for the Hopkins debating teams will . he held on
Thursday, March 15, at 1 o'clock,
in the assembly hall of the Civil
Engineering Building. All graduates and undergraduates are eligible for competition.
The subject of the tryouts is the
subject of the recent seniorjunior debate, "Resolved, That,
constitutionality waived, legislation providing for the compulsory
arbitration of all labor disputes
in interstate railways and prohibiting all strikes and lockouts
in such railways should be enacted."
The speech of each contestant
will be limited to three minutes;
in addition, a short period of rebuttal argument will be required.
Six positions are open—the two
speakers of each team, and the
two alternates. The judge of the
tryouts will be Dr. John C.
French.
The debating triangle between
North Carolina, Virginia and
Hopkins has now been in existence for four years, in the last
three of which Hopkins has been
victorious. The triangle itself, in
which each university sends out
two teams, neither of which debate upon their home ground, has
proved to be most successful,
and, since its inauguration, has
attracted attention in collegiate
debating circles throughout the
country.
This season will be the first in
which the positions of adviser
and alternate on the Hopkins
team have been combined. Following the custom begun last
year, each 'Varsity debater will
be awarded a gold •"H."
The triangular debate between
the three universities will take
place this year on April 28. The
date had first been set one week
earlier, but was postponed because of the breakup in work invariably brought about by the
Easter vacation.
The debate at Hopkins on that
night will be between the universities of North Carolina and Virginia, to be held in the assembly
hall of the Civil Engineering
Building.
The choice of the subject of the
debate, from all indications,
seems to have been a peculiarly
happy one. The question of compulsory arbitration of labor disputes in interstate railways is one
of the most important before the
public eye, and is being debated
by colleges and universities everywhere.

A Chance for the Freshmen.

There are certain -customs existing in most American colleges
and universities which. are decidedly symbolic. Such. a custom
is the almost universal "Cap
Night," when the freshmen of the
institution, gathering about a
bonfire on time campus, throw into it the headgear which, until
that night, had so definitely fixed
their status in the college world.
The tradition signifies more than
the mere celebration of an obvious fact—Lit represents the ending of the period of probation,
and the admission of the freshman, with all rights and. privileges, into the fuller phases of the
college life.
The period during which the
heads of the Hopkins freshmen
must be adorned by the sign of innocence and- submission expires
with the commencement of the
Easter vacation. This, be it remembered, is time first year in
which the wearing of those caps
has been required—it would be
shame indeed if the freshmen had
no better sense of the eternal fitness of things than to inaugurate
their freedom from bondage by
carelessly stuffing the discarded

cap into a convenient ash can.
Rather should there be a mighty
blaze on the scar in the landscape
which, one 'day, will be the
chemical laboratory, with silhouetted figures leaping about it,
'performing mysterious rites; with
weird shadows dancing on the
facades of the buildings, and
barbaric yells rising rhythmically.
The custom is not absolutely
necessary, of course—the_ welfare
of the University does not. vitally
depend upon the exact manner in
which the freshmen observe the
ending of their period of bondage.
But there is already so much
smugness in the Homewood air,
so great a disposal on the part of
undergraduates to.regulate their
lives on a strictly utilitarian
basis, that the introduction of a
symbolic rite into the freshman
life can not be regarded as a
thing wholly undesirable.

At a' recent meeting of the
board of trustees an addition to
the department of economics was
made in the appointment of an
associate professor in insurance.
Dr. Leo Wolman (A. B., Johns
Hopkins University 1911, and
Ph. D. 1914) has been chosen to
fill the position.
In 1914-15, Dr. Wolman was
acting-professor of economics in
Hobart College. Last year he
conducted a series of lectures on
life insurance at Hopkins under
the auspices of the Baltimore Association of Life Underwriters.
It was, this course, begun by the
Baltimore association, which was
largely instrumental in the establishment of the present system of
evening courses in business eco•
nomics;
Dr. Wolman,is now teaching at
the University of Michigan as an
instructor in economics, and is
returning to Hopkins next year
as associate professor in insurance.

On Thursday, March 8, Mr.
John H. K. Shannahan, who is•
connected with the Bethlehem
Steel interests at Sparrows Point,
gave a lecture, accompanied by
moving pictures, before the Hopkins Engineering Society. His
subject was the manufacture of
steel.
The lecture and the pictures
covered the whole process, from
the mining of the ore to the finished steel rails. Mr. Shannahan
first described the manner Of mining the ore in Cuba, where most
of the ore for Sparows Point is
procured, then traced the ore
from the mines to the ships and
from the ships,to the furnaces at
Sparrows Point. The unloading
of the ore, the blast furnaces, the
Bessether converter's, the open
hearth furnaces, and the• rolling
mills were all accurately pictured
and described, and finally —the
finished rails were shown as they
were loaded on cars for shipment.
The pictures showed clearly the
process of manufacturing steel
and, incidentally, gave an excellent idea of the magnitude of the
steel plants at Sparrows Point.

SENIOR AND JUNIOR BANQUETS

The first class banquet of the
year will be held on the night of
March 22, when the Class of 1917
will feast together for the last
time as undergraduates

banquet of the juniors will take
place one week later, on March
29, and the two lower classes will
follow in the early part of April.

an affair upholding, in all respects, the senioral dignity—at
the same time, however, the ban-

quet committee has given assurances that neither the menu nor
the spirit is to have staidness as
its predominating characteristic.
1917 is to have as noteworthy
guests of honor as a graduating
class was ever fortunate enough
to secure. President Goodnow,
Dean Brush and • Prof. Thomas
have been requested to serve in
that capacity, and there is a
strong likelihood that all of the
three will accept. Among the
members of the class who will
speak are Frederick P. Hall,
Trueman Thompson, Paul Sutton

and others.
While definite arrangements
have not as yet been completed,
it is almost certain that the banquet will be. held at the Rennert.
It is rumored that several novel
features are in preparation for
the occasion, but none of these
has been divulged.
The banquet of the juniors is to
be of a distinctly philosophical
tinge. Not only is Dr. Henry
Slonimsky to. be the guest of
honor, but evenr the dishes are to
be selected according to principles
both ethical and logical.

DR.LEO WOLMAN TO RETURN TO
HOPKINS ASSOCIATE PROFESSOR

TELLS ENGINEERING STUDENTS
HOW STEEL IS MANUFACTURED

At a' recent meeting of the
board of trustees an addition to
the department of economics was
made in the appointment of an
associate professor in insurance.
Dr. Leo Wolman (A. B., Johns
Hopkins University 1911, and
Ph. D. 1914) has been chosen to
fill the position.
In 1914-15, Dr. Wolman was
acting-professor of economics in
Hobart College. Last year he
conducted a series of lectures on
life insurance at Hopkins under
the auspices of the Baltimore Association of Life Underwriters.
It was, this course, begun by the
Baltimore association, which was
largely instrumental in the establishment of the present system of
evening courses in business eco•
nomics;
Dr. Wolman,is now teaching at
the University of Michigan as an
instructor in economics, and is
returning to Hopkins next year
as associate professor in insurance.

On Thursday, March 8, Mr.
John H. K. Shannahan, who is•
connected with the Bethlehem
Steel interests at Sparrows Point,
gave a lecture, accompanied by
moving pictures, before the Hopkins Engineering Society. His
subject was the manufacture of
steel.
The lecture and the pictures
covered the whole process, from
the mining of the ore to the finished steel rails. Mr. Shannahan
first described the manner Of mining the ore in Cuba, where most
of the ore for Sparows Point is
procured, then traced the ore
from the mines to the ships and
from the ships,to the furnaces at
Sparrows Point. The unloading
of the ore, the blast furnaces, the
Bessether converter's, the open
hearth furnaces, and the• rolling
mills were all accurately pictured
and described, and finally —the
finished rails were shown as they
were loaded on cars for shipment.
The pictures showed clearly the
process of manufacturing steel
and, incidentally, gave an excellent idea of the magnitude of the
steel plants at Sparrows Point.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 12, 1917.
SENIOR AND JUNIOR BANQUETS
LATTER PART OF THIS MONTH

The first class banquet of the
year will be held on the night of
March 22, when the Class of 1917
will feast together for the last
time as undergraduates
The
banquet of the juniors will take
place one week later, on March
29, and the two lower classes will
follow in the early part of April.
The banquet of 1917 is to be
an affair upholding, in all respects, the senioral dignity—at
the same time, however, the ban-

quet committee has given assurances that neither the menu nor
the spirit is to have staidness as
its predominating characteristic.
1917 is to have as noteworthy
guests of honor as a graduating
class was ever fortunate enough
to secure. President Goodnow,
Dean Brush and • Prof. Thomas
have been requested to serve in
that capacity, and there is a
strong likelihood that all of the
three will accept. Among the
members of the class who will
speak are Frederick P. Hall,
Trueman Thompson, Paul Sutton

and others.
While definite arrangements
have not as yet been completed,
it is almost certain that the banquet will be. held at the Rennert.
It is rumored that several novel
features are in preparation for
the occasion, but none of these
has been divulged.
The banquet of the juniors is to
be of a distinctly philosophical
tinge. Not only is Dr. Henry
Slonimsky to. be the guest of
honor, but evenr the dishes are to
be selected according to principles
both ethical and logical.

1917 BASEBALL SCHEDULE
Lacrosse Squad Fast Rounding into Shape.
Many Veterans Available and Plenty
New Material at Hand — First
Game Only Few Weeks Off.

Although the lacrosse team has
been kept indoors by the long
spell of bad weather during the
past few weeks, yet the men are,
nevertheless, slowly rounding into
shape and several very sharp
scrimmages have been held in the
cage.
Coach Reaney Wolfe, however,
hopes to have the squad outdoors
sometime this week, for with the
first game but a couple of weeks
off, and the Yale and Cornell contests following it during the next
week, a great deal of time will
have to be devoted to the developing of teamwork—a thing• which
it is practically impossible to do
in the narrow limits of the cage.
With the unusually large number of "H" and "H. A. A." men
left over from last season, the
prospects for this year's team are
very bright. There is quite a bit
of good, new material, too, in the
shape both of freshmen who have
had experience at prep schools and
of upperclassmen, who are out for
the team for the first time.
For the attack this year there
are Captain Johnny Knipp, ex
Captain "Eggy" Sutton, "Tabby"
Sutton and "Bill" Swartz, all of
whom have had two years on the
'Varsity squad. Among the best
of the new men in these positions
are Howard Knipp, Sam Silverstein and Dick Holmes from Poly,
and "Shorty" ,Stuart from City
College.
In the midfield there is "Dick"
Woodward, "Al" Wolfe, "Bobby"
Hoffman and -Howard Wilson
from last season, and;"Tiff" Williams and "Bill" Strom, both
sophomores out for the first time.
On the defense there are Henry
Baker, "Doc" Brooks, "Ferdy"
Meyer and "Herb" Baxley, all experienced men, and Turner, Stanley, Golder and Reaney, who are
showing up very well.
At goal there is the old reliable
"Eddie" Stuart and "Hank" Chalmers, who though manager of the
ball team last year, found time to
give quite a respectable exhibition
as goal tender for the scrubs and
for his class team.
